Consider it's a value object, and I simply need to add a property, 
along with a getter and setter.  I don't write tests for that 
everytime.  (We have a BaseTestCase with a checkProperties() method 
that automatically does this for us via introspection.)


> It's the last step that leads you to see that your TestCase is doing
> too much is a candidate to be factored into smaller objects.
> 
> I have worked on a project where test cases quickly became 
difficult to
> understand because of the massive amount of test setup -- mostly
> priming a database with known data. None of our attempts to solve 
the
> problem were entirely satisfying and the team did not agree to let 
me
> test the business logic entirely separately from the persistence
> mechanism. The result was this: after not seeing a certain TestCase 
for
> a few days it would take 10 minutes or so to remember or re-
understand
> what was going on. Also, changes to the test setup had cascading
> effects on the rest of the tests. If I had just created a new 
TestCase,
> I could have factored the real commonality up and kept the details
> separate. That would certainly have helped, and this explains why I
> have adopted that technique as a habit.
> 

I have a similar problem on my current project.  I'm writing a 
persistence layer.  Loosely speaking, my tests take an object graph, 
persist it, read it from the persistence layer, and validate it's 
structure.  The important thing is, and this is where we share a 
common problem, there is a lot of setup involved.  In my case, to 
construct an object graph everytime a test is run.  My approach was 
to create a seperate class (named DAOTestFixture, of all things) 
which constructs and contains the object graph.  I simply create an 
instance of this class from the setUp() method in all my DAO 
TestCases.  At this point, I have about eight DAOs and corresponding 
TestCases that reuse this test fixture.  Plus, I get to use inner 
classes, reap all the benefits, and there is nothing to stop me from 
refactoring those TestCases into seperate inner classes should I want 
to in the future.  If I ever find I need to share a TestCase across 
classes (would this ever happen?), I suppose I could refactor it into 
it's own freestanding class.
